HDG.FS.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Aristotle’s Physics, must pass through this book to enter philosophy, can replace entire library of philosophical works

HDG.FS.content: God as Summum Ens, actus purus essendi—how does Aristotle’s energeia become actualitas? > Romans understood ergon, energeia, on basis of AGERE, “to make,” in an ontic sense, so Summum ens becomes CREATOR, ENS CREATUM (INCREATUM) > ontic determination of actualitas together w/ Aquinas’ Summum Ens w/ Ipsum esse, ontology suppresses possibility for question of Being > to restore (weider einsetzen) philosophy to its own essence: purge (entlasten) it of its Christian element

HDG.FS.linkedContent: God as Summum Ens, actus purus essendi—how does Aristotle’s energeia become actualitas? > Romans understood ergon, energeia, on basis of AGERE, “to make,” in an ontic sense, so Summum ens becomes CREATOR, ENS CREATUM (INCREATUM) > ontic determination of actualitas together w/ Aquinas’ Summum Ens w/ Ipsum esse, ontology suppresses possibility for question of Being > to restore (weider einsetzen) philosophy to its own essence: purge (entlasten) it of its Christian element

HDG.FS.content: Plato names eidōlon as mē on (“un-being”), distinguishes from ouk on, sheer non-being [cf. pp. 39, 42] > eidōlon also distinguished from eidos, that which shows itself, what one sees > but one can’t reach eidos w/out eidōlon, table obscured by wood of which it’s made > Aristotle brings Ideas back to earth, eidos becomes morphē of a tode ti in motion/rest: kinēsis (and for Aristotle all moves) defined as energeai (entelecheia), thus energeia highest determination of being
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Plato names eidōlon as mē on (“un-being”), distinguishes from ouk on, sheer non-being [cf. pp. 39, 42] > eidōlon also distinguished from eidos, that which shows itself, what one sees > but one can’t reach eidos w/out eidōlon, table obscured by wood of which it’s made > Aristotle brings Ideas back to earth, eidos becomes morphē of a tode ti in motion/rest: kinēsis (and for Aristotle all moves) defined as energeai (entelecheia), thus energeia highest determination of being

HDG.FS.content: [Heidegger going to clarify misunderstandings of Seinsfrage] > history of metaphysics has given many answers to Seinsfrage, e.g. Aristotle say energeia, not upokeimenon, latter an interpretation of beings not Being [upokeimenon as presencing (Anwesen) of island, the being as it lets itself be seen, island lies in sea]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: [Heidegger going to clarify misunderstandings of Seinsfrage] > history of metaphysics has given many answers to Seinsfrage, e.g. Aristotle say energeia, not upokeimenon, latter an interpretation of beings not Being [upokeimenon as presencing (Anwesen) of island, the being as it lets itself be seen, island lies in sea]

HDG.FS.content: for Greeks, phenomenon is the thing in itself (an abyss btwn Aristotle & Kant) > unity of ta onta and ta phainomena impossible for Kant > the being has become an ob-ject (res obstans), expression “object” has no correlate in Geek

HDG.FS.content: Aristotle asks what’s extant (seiend) in time?—this is a reduction, a temporal predetermination is operative > for Kant, time conceived in horizon of ob-jectivity, that which holds itself steady in constant flow of changing now > Heidegger explains how short-circuiting of meditation on time covred over meaning of being > “thinking must consequently attempt to further a new—non-metaphysical—way of thinking time [overcoming metaphysics], not governed, surreptitiously, by ontological presupposition of beinghood of time, which concentrates only on what presences

HDG.FS.content: Heidegger on movedness (Bewegtheit), central to Aristotle’s Physics, but not in Kant’s table of categories: Kant didn’t unfold relation of movedness to being

HDG.FS.content: Descartes/Pascal laugh about “motus est actus…” because can’t view what showed itself clearly to Aristotle: kinēsis, movedness as phenomenon > since Galileo, phora masters entire field, mathematical project of nature on basis (aufgrund) of homogenous space [nature as calculable, as masterable, Berechenbarkeit, Beherrschung]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Descartes/Pascal laugh about “motus est actus…” because can’t view what showed itself clearly to Aristotle: kinēsis, movedness as phenomenon > since Galileo, phora masters entire field, mathematical project of nature on basis (aufgrund) of homogenous space [nature as calculable, as masterable, Berechenbarkeit, Beherrschung]

HDG.FS.content: technology not grounded in physics, physics grounded in essence of technology > [Kant establishes program of program] physics observes nature as succession [series, sequence] of things, not as course of things emerging (hervorgehenden) from each other [like Aristotle]

HDG.FS.content: Hegel’s Logic presents God’s thought before creation [?] > “creation” as production (Herstellung) of world > via Aristotle, before creation, God thinks eidos of world, totality of categories: Hegel’s ontology presents ontology from which God takes measure of his creation (Kant’s intuitus originarius)

HDG.FS.content: both Plato & Aristotle put forth 1st determination of being of beings: presencing (Anwesen)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: both Plato & Aristotle put forth 1st determination of being of beings: presencing (Anwesen)

HDG.FS.content: scholastic word objectum is translation of Greek word antikeimenon, but keisthai of antikeimenon means already lying before > whereas object, via representation, brought to halt in an “over and against (im Gegenüber)” > Greek experience of already lying before (and from itself) doesn’t require representation play role in positing being > Aristotle interprets phusis from poiēsis, bringing-forth into open—not modern notion of production (set into availability [Herstellen in die Verfügbarkeit])

motif.name: TRANSLATION / BABEL in TB (BENJAMIN'S "TASK OF THE TRANSLATOR")
motif.title: TRANSLATION / BABEL in TB (BENJAMIN'S "TASK OF THE TRANSLATOR")

HDG.WL.content: Aristotle: vocal sounds a show of the passions in a soul
HDG.WL.linkedContent: Aristotle: vocal sounds a show of the passions in a soul

HDG.WL.content: acc. Aristotle [classical architectonic (Baugefüge) structure of language], letters show sounds, sounds show passions of soul, passions of soul show matters that arouse them (be-treffenden Sachen) > showing (Zeigen) holds up this classical structure > relation btwn Showing and what it shows (Gezeigten) becomes conventional relation btwn sign (Zeichen) & its signification (Bezeichnetem) > transformation (Änderung) of sign from something that shows (Zeigenden) to something that designates (Bezeichnenden): a change in the nature of truth
HDG.WL.linkedContent: acc. Aristotle [classical architectonic (Baugefüge) structure of language], letters show sounds, sounds show passions of soul, passions of soul show matters that arouse them (be-treffenden Sachen) > showing (Zeigen) holds up this classical structure > relation btwn Showing and what it shows (Gezeigten) becomes conventional relation btwn sign (Zeichen) & its signification (Bezeichnetem) > transformation (Änderung) of sign from something that shows (Zeigenden) to something that designates (Bezeichnenden): a change in the nature of truth

HDG.OHF.content: re: Aristotle’s Peri Ermēneias, solely important [in this context] re: history of meaning of word: discourse (Rede) makes something accessible (zugänglich), brings out into open, ready to hand (vorhanden) > thus logos has distinctive possibility of alētheuein (being-true), making what was concealed unconcealed [comes to light through logos]

motif.name: CALL AND RESPONSE (WELCOME OF THE OTHER, ETHICAL OPENING)
motif.title: CALL AND RESPONSE (WELCOME OF THE OTHER, ETHICAL OPENING)

HDG.OHF.linkedContent: re: Aristotle’s Peri Ermēneias, solely important [in this context] re: history of meaning of word: discourse (Rede) makes something accessible (zugänglich), brings out into open, ready to hand (vorhanden) > thus logos has distinctive possibility of alētheuein (being-true), making what was concealed unconcealed [comes to light through logos]

HDG.OHF.content: [history of the concept of “Man”] 1) living being endowed w/ reason (via Aristotle) 2) person or personhood (Christian explication guided by Revelation in Old Testament) > but logos never meant “reason” for Aristotle, but discourse (Rede), conversation (Gespräch): man as a being that has its world in mode (Weise) of something addressed (der Angesprochenen) [man in language]

motif.name: HIEROGLYPH / PASIGRAPHY / LEIBNIZ / CHINESE / UNIVERSAL LANGUAGE
motif.title: HIEROGLYPH / PASIGRAPHY / LEIBNIZ / CHINESE / UNIVERSAL LANGUAGE

HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [history of the concept of “Man”] 1) living being endowed w/ reason (via Aristotle) 2) person or personhood (Christian explication guided by Revelation in Old Testament) > but logos never meant “reason” for Aristotle, but discourse (Rede), conversation (Gespräch): man as a being that has its world in mode (Weise) of something addressed (der Angesprochenen) [man in language]

HDG.OHF.content: [phenomenology beyond dialectic] dialectic directionless (richtungslos) when no Grundblick in direction of (auf) the subject matter (Sache), a rationality testing/proving itself by looking this way (i.e. not dialectically) [Heidegger uses rationality affirmatively here?] > all dialectic lives from table of others, Hegel: “this traditional material” (Plato, Aristotle) “extremely importance source, indeed a necessary condition [and] presupposition to be gratefully acknowledged” (Science of Logic) > dialectic is double-sidedly un-radical: 1) lives from hand to mouth 2) eloquent about readymade material
